questions.text: Two hours after undergoing elective cholecystectomy with general anesthesia, a 41-year-old woman is evaluated for decreased mental status. BMI is 36.6 kg/m2. Respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 126/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows the endotracheal tube in normal position. She does not respond to sternal rub and gag reflex is absent. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows normal PO2 and PCO2 levels. Which of the following anesthetic properties is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytochrome P450 system is responsible for the breakdown of various drugs (e.g., theophylline, warfarin). Therefore, low cytochrome P450 activity can increase the effects of certain drugs. Anesthetic agents, however, are generally eliminated by redistribution into body tissues (muscle, viscerae, and adipose tissue) after diffusing out of the CNS.

B) INCORRECT:

Anesthetics with a low brain-blood partition coefficient (e.g., desflurane) require only low drug concentrations to diffuse into the brain tissue. Therefore, agents with a low brain-blood partition coefficient are associated with fast induction and fast recovery from anesthesia. This patient has delayed recovery from anesthesia.

C) INCORRECT:

The ability of the brain to absorb an anesthetic agent depends on cerebral perfusion. Higher cerebral perfusion is associated with faster induction of the anesthetic. Low cerebral perfusion causes slow induction and weaker effects of the anesthetic, but would not explain the delayed recovery seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Anesthetics with high minimal alveolar concentration (e.g., nitrous oxide) have low potency due to their limited ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Anesthetics with high minimal alveolar concentration (i.e., low potency) are unlikely to cause prolonged emergence from anesthesia.

E) CORRECT:

Inhaled anesthetics with high lipid solubility (e.g., halothane) have a low minimal alveolar concentration and high potency (the greater the lipid solubility, the greater the ability to cross the blood-brain barrier). Because of their high lipid solubility, these drugs can accumulate in lipid tissues. This increases the risk for delayed recovery from anesthesia, especially in obese patients.

Obese patients usually require higher doses of an anesthetic to attain the same peak plasma concentration than patients with a normal BMI.

F) INCORRECT:

Anesthetics with low blood solubility (e.g., nitrous oxide) are associated with rapid induction of anesthesia and recovery. This patient, however, has delayed recovery from anesthesia.
questions.hint: This patient is experiencing delayed emergence from anesthesia. The effect of anesthetics is related to the ability of the agent to redistribute through body tissues.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying the pharmacokinetic properties of two novel inhalational anesthetics and reports the following findings.




Blood-gas partition coefficient

Minimum alveolar concentration



Drug A
0.42
3.20%


Drug B
2.31
7.45%



Which of the following statements best describes the properties of drug A when compared to drug B?

choices.text: More blood soluble and faster induction of anesthesia
More potent and slower recovery from anesthesia
More lipid-soluble and faster recovery from anesthesia
Less lipid soluble and slower induction of anesthesia
Less potent and faster induction of anesthesia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug A has a lower blood-gas partition coefficient than drug B and, therefore, has a lower solubility in blood.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug A has a lower blood-gas partition coefficient than drug B and, therefore, a lower solubility in blood. The less soluble an anesthetic is in blood, the more quickly it diffuses out to the alveoli, which decreases the recovery time of the anesthetic. Thus, drug A has a faster recovery time compared to drug B.

C) CORRECT:

Drug A has a lower MAC and therefore higher potency than drug B. Higher potency anesthetics are more lipid-soluble, which increases interaction with hydrophobic neuronal membranes. Drug A also has lower solubility in blood, as indicated by a lower blood-gas partition coefficient. The less soluble an anesthetic is in blood, the more quickly it diffuses out to the CNS, which decreases the induction time. It also diffuses more quickly from the blood into the alveoli when the alveolar partial pressure of the anesthetic is decreased postoperatively, which hastens recovery.

The inhalational anesthetic nitrous oxide, which has a high MAC and low blood solubility, has relatively low potency and lipid solubility but is associated with rapid induction and recovery. Inhalational anesthetics such as halothane and isoflurane, which have a low MAC and high blood solubility, have a relatively high potency and lipid solubility but are associated with slower induction and recovery.

D) INCORRECT:

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is inversely proportional to lipid solubility. Drug A has a lower MAC than drug B and therefore is more lipid soluble. In addition, drug A has a lower blood-gas partition coefficient than drug B and there has lower solubility in blood. The less soluble an anesthetic is in blood, the more quickly it diffuses out to the CNS, which decreases the induction time of the anesthetic. Thus, drug A has a faster induction time compared to drug B.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug A has a lower minimum alveolar concentration and therefore higher potency than drug B.
questions.hint: The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is inversely proportional to the potency of an inhaled anesthetic. The blood-gas partition coefficient is directly proportional to the solubility of an anesthetic in blood.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Two weeks ago, while visiting Guatemala, she had an emergency appendectomy under general inhalational anesthesia. During the surgery, she received a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F) and blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies show:


Alkaline phosphatase
132 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
760 U/L


Bilirubin



Total
3.8 mg/dL


Direct
3.1 mg/dL


Anti-HAV IgG
positive


Anti-HAV IgM
negative


Anti-HBs
positive


HBsAg
negative


Anti-HCV antibodies
negative


Abdominal ultrasonography shows an enlarged liver. A biopsy of the liver shows massive centrilobular necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Excessive lysis of red blood cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive lysis of red blood cells can occur postoperatively due to hemolytic transfusion reactions. This patient's transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells during surgery may have caused a hemolytic transfusion reaction. However, clinical features (e.g., fever, chills, nausea, flank pain, allergic symptoms) would have appeared shortly after transfusion and laboratory findings would most likely show indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Furthermore, the findings on this patient's liver biopsy are not consistent with a hemolytic transfusion reaction.

B) INCORRECT:

While acalculous cholecystitis can manifest with postoperative jaundice and increased ALP levels, this diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of a positive Murphy sign and evidence of gallbladder inflammation on ultrasound (e.g., gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid). Moreover, very high AST levels and the finding on this patient's liver biopsy are not consistent with acalculous cholecystitis.
Image Description:

Ultrasound gallbladder (transabdominal; longitudinal plane)

The gallbladder is dilated and its wall (red overlay) is thickened. The layered appearance of the wall (hypoechoic stripe between two echogenic lines) is the result of inflammation and edema. Dependent biliary sludge (green overlay) is visible.

Many diseases cause gallbladder wall thickening. Ultrasound findings in acute acalculous cholecystitis can include mural thickening, dilatation, pericholecystic fluid, hyperemia, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign. The presence of several ultrasound criteria increases diagnostic accuracy for cholecystitis. In this case, the additional feature of gallbladder distention was helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

While viral hepatitis is an uncommon cause of postoperative hepatitis, it may result from a hospital outbreak or an exacerbation of chronic hepatitis. However, given this patient's hepatitis antibody panel, viral hepatitis is unlikely. This patient is positive for anti-HAV IgG but negative for anti-HAV IgM, indicating a previous hepatitis A infection that has resolved. She is also negative for hepatitis C antibodies. In addition, this patient is anti-HBs positive, but HBsAg-negative, indicating either a resolved prior infection or a vaccination. Moreover, viral hepatitis predominantly affects the periportal region unlike this patient with centrilobular necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Trauma to the bile duct is a common complication of upper-abdominal surgery, especially cholecystectomy, and can manifest with acute hepatitis, which is seen in this patient. Subsequent scarring of the bile duct may lead to stricture formation, which in turn causes cholestasis. However, this complication is rare after appendectomy. Moreover, liver biopsy would show intraparenchymal cholestasis (not centrilobular necrosis), manifesting as bile pigment accumulation.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's acute postoperative hepatitis is highly suggestive of halothane hepatitis. Halothane hepatitis commonly leads to elevated serum aminotransferases, elevated bilirubin, eosinophilia, and slightly elevated alkaline phosphatase, as seen in this patient. This patient's symptoms began 13 days following surgery, which is consistent with the timeframe for postoperative onset of halothane hepatitis (2 days to 3 weeks). Liver biopsy is not necessary for diagnosis but typically shows massive centrilobular hepatic necrosis.

Halothane is not commonly used as an anesthetic in the United States (and most other industrialized countries) because of its side effects. Instead, it has been replaced with other inhalational anesthetics, such as desflurane, sevoflurane, or isoflurane. However, halothane is still frequently used in developing countries because it is less expensive than other substances.
questions.hint: After undergoing surgery, this patient developed jaundice, fever, vomiting, and tender hepatomegaly, with highly elevated serum transaminases, which indicates acute postoperative hepatitis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man undergoes orthopedic surgery for a leg fracture that he has sustained in a motorbike accident. After induction of anesthesia with desflurane, the patient's respiratory minute ventilation decreases notably. Which of the following additional effects is most likely to occur in response to this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increases in glomerular filtration rate would be unexpected after administration of an inhaled anesthetic such as desflurane. Desflurane reduces cardiac output, which in turn reduces renal plasma flow and the glomerular filtration rate.

B) INCORRECT:

An increased cerebral metabolic rate would be unexpected after administration of desflurane. In fact, inhaled anesthetics cause a decrease in cerebral metabolic rate.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased seizure threshold is a side effect of several medications such as bupropion and tramadol. Desflurane, on the other hand, acts to suppress seizure activity, especially at higher doses.

D) CORRECT:

Increased intracranial pressure results from administration of inhaled anesthetics, including desflurane. Fluorinated inhalational anesthetics increase cerebral blood flow by a somewhat unknown mechanism, thereby increasing intracranial pressure. This is a consequence of the Monro-Kellie theorem.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased responsiveness of the area postrema is the mechanism of antiemetic medications such as ondansetron. Desflurane, on the other hand, stimulates the area postrema and causes postoperative nausea and vomiting.

F) INCORRECT:

A decrease in skeletal muscle tone is likely to be seen in this patient. Most anesthetic agents (with the exception of nitrous oxide) produce dose-dependent relaxation of skeletal muscles owing to inhibition of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Among them, desflurane produces the greatest muscle relaxation. They also enhance the activity of succinylcholine and nondepolarizing muscle relaxants.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased myocardial contractility is expected after administration of desflurane. This drug, like other inhaled anesthetics, acts as a direct negative inotrope in addition to stimulating the autonomic nervous system to further reduce inotropy.
questions.hint: Desflurane is a fluorinated inhalational anesthetic.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with a 3-day history of crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. He has not passed flatus or had a bowel movement for 48 hours. Examination reveals diffuse abdominal distension and tympanic abdomen on percussion. He is scheduled for urgent exploratory laparotomy under general anesthesia (see report).


Heart rate
100/min


Blood pressure
115/70 mmHg


Respiratory rate
18/min


Temperature
37.3°C


Plain abdominal radiographs: Multiple dilated loops of small intestine with air-fluid levels
Which of the following anesthetic considerations is most appropriate for preventing further complications?

choices.text: Omit nitrous oxide to prevent expansion of trapped bowel gas
Select halothane to reduce risks associated with high airway pressures

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nitrous oxide is highly soluble and diffuses rapidly into closed air-filled spaces, such as dilated bowel loops in obstruction. Its use can exacerbate gas expansion, increasing intraluminal pressure and risking bowel wall compromise, ischemia, or perforation. This occurs because nitrous oxide enters these spaces faster than nitrogen exits, worsening preexisting gas accumulation. Avoiding nitrous oxide in patients with bowel obstruction is crucial to prevent these complications during anesthesia.

Key learning point: Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in bowel obstruction due to its potential to increase the volume of trapped gas and exacerbate distension.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrous oxide rapidly diffuses into air-filled spaces, increasing volume and pressure. In bowel obstruction, this can worsen distension and impede surgical exposure. Its use is counterproductive in gastrointestinal obstruction due to its potential to exacerbate gas expansion.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal anesthesia is inadequate for exploratory laparotomy, which requires extensive intra-abdominal manipulation and airway protection. It does not provide muscle relaxation or ventilation control, increasing aspiration risk in bowel obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Halothane does not specifically reduce high airway pressures and is associated with myocardial depression and arrhythmogenicity. Modern anesthetic practice favors agents with better cardiovascular profiles and rapid recovery, which halothane lacks.
